00011 namespace Sass {
00012 
00013 
00014   using namespace std;
00015 
00016 
00017   class Context;
00018 
00019   /*
00020    There are a lot of stumbling blocks when trying to port the ruby extend code to C++. The biggest is the choice of
00021    data type. The ruby code will pretty seamlessly switch types between an Array<SimpleSequence or Op> (libsass'
00022    equivalent is the Complex_Selector) to a Sequence, which contains more metadata about the sequence than just the
00023    selector info. They also have the ability to have arbitrary nestings of arrays like [1, [2]], which is hard to
00024    implement using Array equivalents in C++ (like the deque or vector). They also have the ability to include nil
00025    in the arrays, like [1, nil, 3], which has potential semantic differences than an empty array [1, [], 3]. To be
00026    able to represent all of these as unique cases, we need to create a tree of variant objects. The tree nature allows
00027    the inconsistent nesting levels. The variant nature (while making some of the C++ code uglier) allows the code to
00028    more closely match the ruby code, which is a huge benefit when attempting to implement an complex algorithm like
00029    the Extend operator.
00030 
00031    Note that the current libsass data model also pairs the combinator with the Complex_Selector that follows it, but
00032    ruby sass has no such restriction, so we attempt to create a data structure that can handle them split apart.
00033    */
00034 
00035   class Node;
00036   typedef deque<Node> NodeDeque;
00037   typedef shared_ptr<NodeDeque> NodeDequePtr;
00038 
00039   class Node {
00040   public:
00041     enum TYPE {
00042       SELECTOR,
00043       COMBINATOR,
00044       COLLECTION,
00045       NIL
00046     };
00047 
00048                 TYPE type() const { return mType; }
00049     bool isCombinator() const { return mType == COMBINATOR; }
00050     bool isSelector() const { return mType == SELECTOR; }
00051     bool isCollection() const { return mType == COLLECTION; }
00052     bool isNil() const { return mType == NIL; }
00053     bool got_line_feed;
00054 
00055     Complex_Selector::Combinator combinator() const { return mCombinator; }
00056 
00057     Complex_Selector* selector() { return mpSelector; }
00058     const Complex_Selector* selector() const { return mpSelector; }
00059 
00060     NodeDequePtr collection() { return mpCollection; }
00061     const NodeDequePtr collection() const { return mpCollection; }
00062 
00063     static Node createCombinator(const Complex_Selector::Combinator& combinator);
00064 
00065     // This method will clone the selector, stripping off the tail and combinator
00066     static Node createSelector(Complex_Selector* pSelector, Context& ctx);
00067 
00068     static Node createCollection();
00069     static Node createCollection(const NodeDeque& values);
00070 
00071     static Node createNil();
00072 
00073     Node clone(Context& ctx) const;
00074 
00075     bool operator==(const Node& rhs) const;
00076     inline bool operator!=(const Node& rhs) const { return !(*this == rhs); }
00077 
00078 
00079     /*
00080     COLLECTION FUNCTIONS
00081 
00082     Most types don't need any helper methods (nil and combinator due to their simplicity and
00083     selector due to the fact that we leverage the non-node selector code on the Complex_Selector
00084     whereever possible). The following methods are intended to be called on Node objects whose
00085     type is COLLECTION only.
00086     */
00087 
00088     // rhs and this must be node collections. Shallow copy the nodes from rhs to the end of this.
00089     // This function DOES NOT remove the nodes from rhs.
00090     void plus(Node& rhs);
00091 
00092     // potentialChild must be a node collection of selectors/combinators. this must be a collection
00093     // of collections of nodes/combinators. This method checks if potentialChild is a child of this
00094     // Node.
00095     bool contains(const Node& potentialChild, bool simpleSelectorOrderDependent) const;
00096 
00097   private:
00098     // Private constructor; Use the static methods (like createCombinator and createSelector)
00099     // to instantiate this object. This is more expressive, and it allows us to break apart each
00100     // case into separate functions.
00101     Node(const TYPE& type, Complex_Selector::Combinator combinator, Complex_Selector* pSelector, NodeDequePtr& pCollection);
00102 
00103     TYPE mType;
00104 
00105     // TODO: can we union these to save on memory?
00106     Complex_Selector::Combinator mCombinator;
00107     Complex_Selector* mpSelector; // this is an AST_Node, so it will be handled by the Memory_Manager
00108     NodeDequePtr mpCollection;
00109   };
00110 
00111 #ifdef DEBUG
00112   ostream& operator<<(ostream& os, const Node& node);
00113 #endif
00114   Node complexSelectorToNode(Complex_Selector* pToConvert, Context& ctx);
00115   Complex_Selector* nodeToComplexSelector(const Node& toConvert, Context& ctx);
00116 
00117   bool nodesEqual(const Node& one, const Node& two, bool simpleSelectorOrderDependent);
00118 
00119 }

00121 #endif
